article.headline: Holy Cross 67, San Francisco 63
article.story: SAN FRANCISCO (AP) -- Eddie Sutton's new team rallied from a 16-point deficit in regulation, only to blow a six-point lead in overtime. Yet the coach had a spring in his slightly stooped stride as he walked out of San Francisco's still-unfamiliar gym. The swinging emotions of college basketball are nothing new to Sutton, and he's still planning to teach the Dons how to handle it all before he leaves coaching for good. Sutton lost his third straight game as San Francisco's interim coach despite his new players' impressive second-half rally to force overtime in Holy Cross' 67-63 victory Saturday. The 71-year-old Sutton remained stuck on 798 career victories in his first home game with San Francisco (4-11) since taking charge of the struggling program from Jessie Evans on Dec. 26. Though he came back partly to roll his coaching odometer over to 800 wins, Sutton is more interested in teaching one last bunch of young men how to win -- and they almost did it against the preseason Patriot League favorites. "I told our guys at halftime, if I were a season-ticket holder, I'd tear my tickets up and go home," Sutton said of a first half in which his team went 4-for-28 and fell behind by 15 points. "In the second half, they played very well, and should have won the game. ... I thought they displayed some courage." Sutton needed some courage of his own to return to coaching after a decorated career at Arkansas, Kentucky and Oklahoma State. He opened his San Francisco tenure with two road losses in Utah, but the latest defeat showed what might be possible for his Dons, who have lost six straight overall. "I've really had a good time," Sutton said. "We've lost three games, but I've had a good time. I was proud of the way we played in the second half." San Francisco went ahead 61-55 in overtime before the Crusaders (9-3) finished on a 12-2 run. Whether teaching or cheering, Sutton was his usual animated sideline presence as San Francisco got to overtime on two late 3-pointers by Manny Quezada. Adam May scored five points in the final 1:34 of OT for the Crusaders, who won despite going 7:15 between field goals in a drought that extended into overtime. Dior Lowhorn had 24 points and nine rebounds to go with a tongue-lashing from Sutton late in the second half, while Danny Cavic added 12 points. Tim Clifford scored 17 points and Pat Doherty added 16 for the Crusaders. Sutton is the latest hoops luminary to grace the small West Coast Conference school that produced Bill Russell, K.C. Jones and Bill Cartwright. Though Sutton has the second-most career wins behind Bob Knight among active coaches, so far in San Francisco he's only adding to his loss total, which reached 318 with this defeat. He also has been disarmingly blunt about the Dons, saying they have "the least amount of talent that I've ever had" and "a defeatist attitude." His latest result suggests he might be able to change the attitude, at least. "He's had a pretty big effect," said Lowhorn, who also played for Knight at Texas Tech before transferring back home to the Bay Area. "There's no miracle cure for how we've been playing in the past, but in the past 10 days, we've made a lot of changes." But Sutton couldn't be expected to teach his players how to shoot in 10 days. San Francisco opened the game in a 2-for-18 slump, with Lowhorn and Cavic making the Dons' only field goals in the first half. When the Dons botched an inbounds play in the final seconds, Sutton lowered his head into his hands with a chuckle. "I've played for a long time, and that might be the worst half I've ever participated in," Cavic said. "I really don't think we can play any worse, and in a way, that's encouraging." After Christian Hernandez hit two quick 3-pointers early in the second half, the Dons stayed close until Quezada hit 3-pointers with 1:37 and 35 seconds to play in regulation, the second shot set up by a key offensive rebound by Lowhorn. Holy Cross, which finishes its nonconference schedule Tuesday night at Maryland, went scoreless in the final 3:12 of regulation. The Crusaders' cross-country trip from Massachusetts produced the first victory over San Francisco in school history. Sutton's next task will be improving the Dons' winless road record, as their next three games are away from home in conference play. San Francisco won't play on the Hilltop again until Jan. 26 against Saint Mary's.

statistics.name: points
statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.name: fieldGoals
statistics.description: Field Goal makes and attempts.

statistics.name: freeThrows
statistics.description: Free Throw makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.
